 Because you said so?
 
 And wow! I've never seen so many fallacies in one thread. I'll briefly point out the fallacy for each post:
 
 Post:
 1. A type of false dilemma
 2. Poisoning the Well and Ad Hominem
 3. Aside from being hearsay it is also a circumstantial ad hominem 
 4. This is either hearsay or a false claim.
 5. This isn't a logical fallacy. Congrats.
 6. Same as 4. This certainly isn't common knowledge and makes no sense anyway.
 7. Not a fallacy. Good job :)
 8. Classic Ad Hominem
 9. Not a fallacy. And yes, I am confused as well. Cyberateos is actually doing ok other than the first post
 10. Straw man! A simone special (an ad hominem attack right there by me)
 11. Strawman, Appeal to Ridicule
 12. circumstantial ad hominem 
 13. (my post) This is just unrelated and therefore is a fallacy. 
 
 Wow, only 2 out of 13 are not logical fallacies. This is terrible.

Simone:
 
 Is a 7 month fetus more similar to a 7 month newborn or to sperma?
 
 An adequate Law should be based on logical similarities.

The critical factor here is punishing women.
 
 Women must be punished. For whatever strikes the fancy of Cybererratus.

The critical factor here is punishing women.

 I thought the critical factors were (are);
 
 a: When does a child's life begin?
 
 b: When does a new child's rights begin?
 
 c: What are the possible justifications for denying the rights of the new child (if any)?
 
 d: What (if any) should the punishment be for violating the child's rights by killing him or her unjustly?
 
 Can we not (at least) agree on what the "critical factors" are? 
 
 If not, isn't all subsequent debate destined to be non-productive?

Simone:
 
 Is a 7 month fetus more similar to a 7 month newborn or to sperma?
 
 An adequate Law should be based on logical similarities.

 
 I'm amazed you even have to ask this question. Obviously a 7 month old fetus is much more similar to a 7 month old born baby than to sperm. For one thing, it can survive outside of the womb at that stage of development. It is also fully formed. The question is ludicrous assuming it is coming from an allegedly informed adult.

What is a child?

 
 Well that's been the debate up to now,... hasn't it?
 
 Some say that a child is a child and entitled to the life they are living from the earliest moment that science can establish the fact that they are alive and living the life of a new human being in the earliest stages of their individual life. (conception)
 
 While others say that a child is not a child until that new organism lives long enough and develops to an arbitrarily established point,... after which, they or society can not justify denying them their rights or personhood any longer.
 
 There isn't much grey area between the two camps.

post_info.post_title: A Child by any other name,....

An invisible fertilized egg is a child?

An invisible fertilized (human) egg is a child?

 
 (Qualifier added by me)
 
 Unless you have some level of proof that human beings sexually reproduce by way of "metamorphosis?" The answer is Yes. At the very least, (biologically speaking) a (nearly) invisibe fertilized (human) egg is a "child."
 
 Humans don't sexually reproduce and biologically create (in the process) a living "something" which is less than a young human organism; A less than human something that will later (if not interrupted) "morph" into a human being.
 
 I must admit that it would greatly simplify the abortion debate if humans did undergo metamorphosis,... but the fact is they(we) don't.
